Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system. Let's see if we can make sense out of it. The
MU-puzzle consists of strings that can be manipulated according to specific rules. The puzzle is to
prove a certain theorem within this system.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's second three-part invention. Again, it's a variation on the theme and
involves similar structures. The two-part nature of the invention mirrors the two-part nature of the
Dialogue.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a very simple system. It has an
intense and clear structure. The system consists of strings that can be manipulated according to specific
rules. The puzzle is to prove a certain theorem within this system.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. The third part of the three-part Invention. Achilles and the
Tortoise are back, discussing the MU-puzzle and the nature of meaning in mathematics. The Tortoise
wants to prove a theorem in the MU-puzzle, and Achilles is skeptical.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. This is the story of how I came to be written. It is a meta-level
story, not told directly, but via the text of the book. The book's narrative structure is
---

ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle that I call the MU-puzzle, which consists of
strings of the letters M and U. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound puzzle that is an
incarnation of the MU-puzzle.
Two-Part Invention. A "live" version of the Three-Part Invention, presented as a two-part
Dialogue.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a contrived puzzle that I call
the MU-puzzle, which consists of strings of the letters M and U. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet
profound puzzle that is an incarnation of the MU-puzzle.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A sonata written by Achilles, with a logical structure that
conveys the MU-puzzle. The story of the MU-puzzle is presented to the reader as Achilles' story.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle is a contrived puzzle that I call the MU-puzzle,
which consists of strings of the letters M and U. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound puzzle
that is an incarnation of the MU-puzzle.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the reader is asked to
work through several of its confusing and intriguing problems. It is a puzzle in which the
Objective is to find out whether a particular string can be derived in the system.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a very simple system, but it
provides an introduction to the concepts of meaning and form in mathematics, which are central to
GEB. The reader is led through a series of questions about the nature of mathematics and the
human mind.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle is continued, and in the third chapter we explore
the relationship between figure and ground in mathematics, drawing a parallel to the relationship
between the mind and the body.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. The MU-puzzle is continued, and in the
fourth chapter we delve into the concepts of consistency, completeness, and geometry, which are
central to GEB. The reader is led through a series of questions about the nature of mathematics and
the human mind.
Chapter V: Recursive Structures and Processes. The MU-puzzle is continued, and in the fifth
chapter we explore the concepts of recursive structures and processes, which are
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings,
rules, and derivations. It is an abstract axiomatic system, which serves as a model for the way
the MU-puzzle can be solved. The MU-puzzle consists of a single axiom and three rules. The
axiom is "MI", and the rules are: 
1. If a string ends with I, you can add a I at the end of the string.
2. If a string has consecutive Is, you can delete one I from between them.
3. If a string ends with III, you can delete the last III.
The MU-puzzle consists of transforming the axiom "MI" into the theorem "MU".
The key question is: Can the MU-puzzle be solved? That is, can the theorem "MU" be
derived from the given axiom and rules?
The key question is: Can the MU-puzzle be solved? That is, can the theorem "MU" be
derived from the given axiom and rules?
The key question is: Can the MU-puzzle be solved? That is, can the theorem "MU" be
derived from the given axiom and rules?

The key question is: Can the MU-puzzle be solved? That is, can

Edifying Thoughts of a Tobacco Smoker 480
Chapter XVI: Self-Ref and Self-Rep 495
The Magn fierab, Indeed 549
Chapter XVII: Church, Turing, Tarski, and Others 559
SHRDLU, Toy of Man's Designing 586
Chapter XVIII: Artificial Intelligence: Retrospects 594
Contrafactus 633
Chapter XIX: Artificial Intelligence: Prospects 641
Sloth Canon 681
Chapter XX: Strange Loops, Or Tangled Hierarchies 684
Six-Part Ricercar 720
Notes 743
Bibliography 746
Credits 757
Index 759
Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of the MU-puzzle is presented as an example of
a simple formal system, which is a "thinking" system that we can do in our heads. It is a
very simple system, yet from it one can grasp some very basic aspects of formal systems.
The MU-puzzle consists of the three rules that can be used to manipulate strings of letters to
change the string. The problem is to find a string that can be reached from the starting string MU
using these rules. The system is presented, and the reader is asked to try to find a solution.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question of how it is that formal systems
can express something that makes them meaningful. Meaning is not just about the formal
properties of a system but about the concepts inside the system that allow us to construe the
system as "meaningful". The concept of "formal systems" is considered, along with the notion that
the formal properties alone do not explain the meaning of a system. The MU-puzzle is discussed,
and the problem of how the MU-puzzle statement could turn out to be either true or false, but
which we do not know. The question is whether such a system could be "given meaning"
---


---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules,
and levels of description. The MU-puzzle consists of the string "MU" and the three rules for
manipulating strings: a) If you can make a string ending with "U", you can add "U" to the end.
b) If you have "M" followed by any string, you can insert "I" between them. c) If you have "III" in
the middle of a string, you can replace it with "U". The puzzle is to see whether you can get "MU"
from "MI".
The MU-puzzle is a simple version of the more complex puzzle presented in Chapter XI. The
MU-puzzle is discussed at the outset of the book, as an example of a simple formal system. It is
used throughout the book to illustrate the concepts of strings, rules, and levels of description.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The concept of "meaning" and "form" in
mathematics is discussed. The MU-puzzle is revisited here, with the distinction between the
formal and the substantial meaning of " MU". The puzzle is used to illustrate the idea that formal
systems can have multiple levels of meaning
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle that I have used in many logic classes. The MU-puzzle
consists of a string of letters consisting of M and U. The puzzle is to find a way to get from
M to MUU using the fewest number of steps. The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a formal
system, which is a set of axioms and rules of inference. The MU-puzzle is designed to illustrate
the concepts of formal systems, such as the meaning and form in mathematics, and the role of
axioms and rules in determining theorems.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention. In the context of the book, it is a dialogue between
the Tortoise and Achilles. The dialogue explores the concepts of reductionism and emergence, the
two main philosophical approaches that are at odds with each other. Reductionism is the idea that
everything can be explained in terms of simpler elements, and that complex phenomena can be
broken down into simpler ones. Emergence is the opposite: it is the idea that complex phenomena
cannot be fully explained in terms of their simpler components; they give rise to new properties
and behaviors that can't be predicted from the properties of their components. The dialogue is
a very
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple yet profound puzzle that deals with the MU-puzzle: the
problem of turning the string MU into MI by using only certain rules. The MU-puzzle is a
formal system, and the MU-puzzle is a problem about such systems.
The MU-puzzle is a recursive puzzle that can be used to explore the concepts of formal systems,
theorems, and the idea that meaning can be derived from form. It is a simple puzzle that can be
used to introduce the concept of formal systems, and it is used to show how a puzzle can be used to
model formal systems.
The MU-puzzle is a puzzle that is both simple and profound. It is a puzzle that can be used to
introduce the concept of formal systems, and it is used to show how a puzzle can be used to model
formal systems. It is a puzzle that is both simple and profound. It is a puzzle that can be used to
introduce the concept of formal systems, and it is used to show how a puzzle can be used to model
formal systems.

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe of thought-experiments: only the symbols M and U are
available. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound puzzle that explores the concepts of formal
systems, recursion, and self-reference. The MU-puzzle is designed to make the reader think about
the nature of meaning and formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is an example of the concept of reduction, where one
part can be deduced from another. The dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise explores this
concept, with the Tortoise arguing against the idea of reductionism, while Achilles tries to
persuade him otherwise.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the concepts of
meaning and form in mathematics, discussing the nature of mathematical truth, the relationship
between syntax and semantics, and the limits of formal systems.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A musical sonata written by Bach, presented as a metaphor for
the ideas discussed in the preceding chapter. The sonata is played by Achilles, who musically
explores the concepts of meaning and form in mathematics.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the concepts of figure and ground,
which are fundamental to perception and
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the idea of formal
systems, TNT, and the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle in which the MU string must be
generated from the initial string MI, using only certain rules. The puzzle asks whether the MU string
can be generated using only those rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of Gödel's incompleteness
theorem. The MU-puzzle is introduced with the example of the MU-puzzle, leading to an explanation
of formal systems, TNT, and the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle in which the MU string must
be generated from the initial string MI, using only certain rules. The puzzle asks whether the MU string
can be generated using only those rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of Gödel's incompleteness
theorem.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple yet profound puzzle to get the reader started. It concerns a
made-up language called MU, and an MU-puzzle, which is like a maze, that leads the reader to
understand the nature of formal systems. The MU-puzzle is a good way to start because it's simple,
and yet it brings out the key aspects of formal systems. The puzzle also sets the stage for the
subsequent chapters on meaning and form in mathematics, and the MU-Endeavour.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This chapter is about how we give meaning to
mathematical statements, and how we attempt to make our meaning precise. The MU-puzzle is a
good way to start because it's simple, and yet it brings out the key aspects of formal systems. The
puzzle also sets the stage for the subsequent chapters on meaning and form in mathematics, and the
MU-Endeavour.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The third chapter is about the relation between the figure and the
ground in a mathematical and philosophical context. The concept of figure and ground can be
applied to many areas, including mathematics, physics, and computer science. The idea of figure and
ground can also be seen as analogous to
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU, and the reader is
posed the puzzle: can "MU" be derived from the given axioms? The MU-puzzle is a variant of the
game of “Tag” that I have used in many talks and writings, and which I here use to illustrate
Gödel's Theorem.
Two-Part Invention. Another three-part invention by Bach, which serves as a basis for the
second Dialogue. The second Dialogue is a little "symphony" composed by Zeno for two
intelligences: Achilles and the Tortoise. The main point is that the Tortoise has a (sustainable)
argument with Achilles, with Zeno as the conductor. Achilles, being a logophile, loves
logistics and paradoxes, while the Tortoise is a philosophical musing. The dialogue revolves around
their discussion of the nature of infinity.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is used to explain how it is that
strings of symbols can mean something, and that meaning and form are linked. The distinction
between formal systems and “meaningful” systems is discussed. It is shown how such distinctions
have led to a new branch of mathematical logic called “Meaning
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem. The MU-puzzle
consists of a string of letters M and U and the two transformation rules: "you can add a U to the
end of any string ending with M", and "you can double the string by duplicating it". The puzzle is to
find out whether the string "MU" can be obtained from "MI" using only these two rules.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's second invention from the same trio of pieces. This is a two-part
Dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise, and it is written in the style of Lewis Carroll's
"Through the Looking-Glass". The Tortoise challenges Achilles to a game of reasoning, leading to an
explication of the MU-puzzle and the nature of formal systems. In the process, Achilles and the
Tortoise explore the concepts of strings and concatenation, and of the difference between
meaning and form. The Tortoise then tries to get Achilles to think about the nature of recursion
and of levels of meaning, leading to a meta-argument that such systems can never lead to true
comprehension of their own nature.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. A discussion of the
---

in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the concept of
"formal systems" is introduced. The puzzle is to figure out, with the MU-puzzle, whether the
string "GODESS" can be derived. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of the MU-puzzle in
GEB. The MU-puzzle is a mathematical puzzle consisting of strings of the letters M, I, and U.
The puzzle is to figure out whether the string "GODESS" can be derived in the system. The system
has four rules, which are presented. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of the MU-puzzle in GEB.
The MU-puzzle is a mathematical puzzle consisting of strings of the letters M, I, and U.
The puzzle is to figure out whether the string "GODESS" can be derived in the system. The system
has four rules, which are presented.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question is whether mathematics is
something we invent or discover. The discussion ranges from Platonism to Formalism.

mathematics and philosophy is discussed. The discussion is tied to Escher's "Prints"

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Fragment of a much larger system. The MU-puzzle consists
of the three rules:

Rule 1: x -> xU
Rule 2: Ux -> xU
Rule 3: If x and y are on the blackboard, then xy -> yx

The MU-puzzle starts with MU and the question is whether MUI can be derived from MU. This is
a simple puzzle to illustrate the concept of formal systems. The MU-puzzle is a variant of the famous
Pentagon puzzle.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. A discussion on how meaning in mathematics is
not just about formal correctness, but also about the deeper understanding. It's about the quest to
find out what makes mathematical statements true, and how we can be sure. This is a discussion
that touches upon the philosophy of mathematics. It is here that the MU-puzzle is used to
demonstrate the distinction between syntax and semantics.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle is used again to talk about the relationship between
a concept and its negation, as in the relationship between a bird and the figure that is the ground, or
the background, in which the bird is outlined.
Chapter IV: Consistency
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle that helps the reader understand the notions of
formal systems, alphabets, and rules of inference. The MU-puzzle is a simple case of a formal
system. The puzzle is: Starting from the string M, can you get to MU using only the given rules?
The MU-puzzle is an example of a purely syntactic system: the string "M" is a single symbol, and
the rules of inference specify how to manipulate it.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is an example of the concept of reduction, that is,
of levels of description and abstraction. The two-part Invention is a set of variations on the theme
of reduction.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Achilles, a hero of the Trojan war, is the subject of a
set of variations. Each variation is a different formal system. The variations are: MU, Ant, Box,
Tortoise, and Frothy.
Contracrostipunctus. By J.S. Bach. This is a set of canons with cross-sections. In this
setting, the cross-sections are presented as problems for the reader to solve. The cross-sections
are: the Goldbach Conjecture, the R
---


---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived "game" of Hofstadter's that is a simple version of
Gödel's incompleteness Theorem. The MU-puzzle consists of a string of letters which can be
"transformed" according to certain rules. Through the MU-puzzle, Hofstadter introduces the idea of
strings, variables, rules of transformation, meaning, and formal systems. The MU-puzzle is a
very simple version of Godel's incompleteness Theorem. It is a string (MUltiplication) puzzle that
can be "played" by anyone, and as such, serves as an accessible way to understand the complex
notions of formal systems and their limitations.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles, after having
solved the MU-puzzle, discuss the nature of mathematical meaning. They explore the question: "What
makes a mathematical statement true?" They contrast Hilbert's Formalism with Platonism, and
touch upon other philosophical viewpoints. The MU-puzzle is a very simple version of Godel's
incompleteness Theorem. It is a string (MUltiplication) puzzle that can be "played" by anyone, and
as such, serves as
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the puzzle of MU being
provable within the system is given. The system is a contrived one, consisting of strings of M's and
U's. The puzzle is whether MU can be derived. The MU-puzzle is a very simple self-referential system
that is similar to the MU-puzzle in Gödel, Escher, Bach. It is given an extensive treatment, with
various levels of approach. The system is a string rewriting system with two axioms and two
rules of inference. The system is discussed in depth, with the goal of getting the reader to understand
how to approach and solve such systems.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention, which is a set of two complementary pieces, each
involving different instruments, but together forming a complete and coherent work. The two-part
invention is an analogy for the structure of the book, which is also divided into two parts: Part I and
Part II. The two-part structure is similar to the musical structure of the book.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question of how formal systems can model
mathematical reasoning is discussed, and the notion that formal systems can be given "
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the puzzle is to see how
Gödel's Theorem shows that the system cannot be both consistent and complete. The MU-puzzle
is a good example of a purely mathematical system, and yet paradoxical, and it is used to
introduce the idea of strings and rules, of encoding and concatenation.
Two-Part Invention. A "consonant" and "dissonant" counterpoint, with the common time of two
beats. The musical analogy is continued in the discussion of the MU-puzzle, with the idea that
completeness can never be reached in such systems. The analogy is given between the MU-puzzle
and the human mind, and the idea that the "fixed stars" of mathematics and logic can never be the
only source of truth, and that formal systems are not sufficient for the human mind's potential.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Achilles, a hero of the Trojan war, was already a
supremely skilled fugue player, so the task of writing a sonata for him was especially difficult.
But since Achilles is so powerful, he can "think" in terms of simple concatenation and/or
substitution, but he cannot "under
---

requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"

and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A Simple Example. The MU-puzzle consists of the two strings M and
U, and the three rules for transforming them. It is a simple example of a formal system, which is
a structure that can be applied to many different kinds of systems. The MU-puzzle is a very simple
example of such a system. The MU-puzzle consists of the two strings M and U, and the three rules
for transforming them. The aim is to see if the string UU can be derived in the system. The rules
are:
1. Any string ending with U may be appended with a U.
2. Any string consisting of M, U, and U can be changed to M.
3. Any string may be duplicated by writing it again.

The MU-puzzle is a very simple example of a formal system, which is a structure that can be applied
to many different kinds of systems. The system consists of an initial string and some rules for
changing strings. The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a formal system, which is a structure that can
be applied to many different kinds of systems.

The MU-puzzle is a very simple example of a formal system, which is a structure that can be applied
to many different kinds of

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple yet profound puzzle that illustrates the concepts of
formal systems, axioms, and rules of inference. The MU-puzzle consists of a string of letters which
can be transformed according to specific rules. The puzzle is to find out whether a certain string can be
derived from a given starting string using these rules.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. Explores the relationship between meaning and
form in mathematics. It discusses how the meaning of mathematical statements can be analyzed and
perhaps made rigorous. It also touches on the nature of mathematical truth and the role of axioms in
mathematical systems.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. Discusses the concepts of figure and ground in the context of
art and design, and how these relate to mathematical and logical systems. It delves into the
metaphysical distinctions between "meaning" (the figure) and "背景" (the ground), and how these
distinctions can be applied to understand various systems.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. Explores the concepts of consistency and
completeness in formal systems, relating them to geometry. It discusses the implications of these
concepts for the nature of mathematical truth and the limits of formal systems.
Chapter
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader to start thinking about
strings, recursion, and formal systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This is the longest chapter. It discusses how
mathematical and formal systems work, with several examples. It ends up playing a key role in
the story of how the MU-puzzle might be approached. It also ties into the concepts of formal
systems, meaning, and the nature of mathematics itself.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. This is a piece that I have written that is in the spirit of
Escher's prints. It discusses the relationship between the figure and the ground in various contexts,
including mathematics and music. It also introduces some concepts that will be needed in the later
chapters.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. This chapter deals with the notions of
consistency, completeness, and formal systems. The famous theorem of Gödel is discussed in
depth, and the implications of what it means for the formal systems of arithmetic and geometry.
Chapter V: Recursive Structures and Processes. This is an introduction to recursive structures and
processes, with several examples. It gives the basic idea of recursion, and how it can be used to
define complex patterns and
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe consisting of the letters M and U, with four
rules of manipulation. The puzzle is to find out which strings can be transformed into MU.
The MU-puzzle is a simple version of Gödel's famous Theorem, which demonstrates the inherent
limitations of formal systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore with some
tortoise and hare logic (Zeno again) about how questions of meaning and form arise in
mathematics. In particular, they examine the nature of definitions, the role of formal systems in
mathematics, and the relationship between syntax and semantics.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the importance of
differentiating between figure and ground (i.e., what you are talking about versus the sentence
that is talking about it) in both mathematics and in life. The concept of self-reference is
introduced here.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. The Tortoise and Achilles explore
some fundamental concepts of formal logic: consistency, completeness, and geometry. The
Tortoise tries to prove the consistency of the MU puzzle, but the system is shown to be
incomplete. The discussion then shifts to the nature of mathematical
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of MU-
completeness. The MU-puzzle is a variant of the MIU puzzle of Hofstadter (1979), which in turn is
based on the work of Lewis Carroll. The MU-puzzle consists of a string of letters consisting of M and U
and the two rules for deriving strings: Rule 1: If a string ends with MU, you can add another MU
to the end. Rule 2: If a string contains MU, you can insert a MU in any place of the string. The
problem is to determine whether a particular target string can be derived from the initial string MU.

The MU-puzzle is a contrived puzzle designed to highlight the concept of MU-completeness, which is
a way of formalizing the idea of computational complexity. MU-completeness is a concept that
might seem abstract at first, but it has deep implications for the field of computer science, particularly
in the study of algorithms and computational resources.

The MU-puzzle is a variant of the MIU puzzle of Hofstadter (1979), which in turn is based on the
work of Lewis Carroll. The MIU puzzle is a well-known puzzle in logic and
---

of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived "game" of strings, which leads to an explanation of
Gödel's Theorem. The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a formal system, which I call “The
Most Underwhelming System” (as the reader will see later). The puzzle is to figure out why the
string "MU" cannot be derived from the initial string "MI" by means of the given rules of the
system. The system consists of a few simple rules, and the MU-puzzle is a good example of a
purely formal system.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules,
and derivations. It is a good introduction to the MU-puzzle, which is a part of the larger story.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part Invention No. 3 (from the Musical Offering) is presented as
the main theme. The first part is "Aria", the second part is "Bassus", and the story of their
improvization is given. The text is followed by a musical rendition of this invention.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the MU-puzzle,
and the nature of formal systems. They also discuss the concepts of meaning and form in
mathematics. The text is followed by a musical rendition of the "Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles".
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. Achilles and the Tortoise explore the concepts of figure and
ground in mathematics and logic, using the MU-puzzle as a case study. They also discuss the
recursion theorem and other related concepts. The text is followed by a musical rendition of the

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple puzzle to get the reader to start thinking about the nature of
mechanical reasoning and mathematical discovery, as well as the idea of formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise explore some aspects of
mechanical reasoning. The Tortoise challenges Achilles to a race, under a system of lemmata (the
Tortoise is a logician), to test whether Achilles is "logically" as sound as the Tortoise. The race
and the lemmata are designed to mirror the reasoning of the MU-puzzle.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria with Diverse Variations. Bach's piece. The story
tells how the MU-puzzle was made, and the MU-puzzle is presented as an analogy to the
process of mathematical discovery.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the MU-puzzle
and the concept of "formal systems." They discuss the nature of "meaning" within formal systems.
The Tortoise brings up the example of geometry and the MU-puzzle, and the discussion continues.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Bach's piece. The story tells how the MU-puzzle was made,
and the
---

Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the notion of strings, rules,
and derivations. It is an imaginary puzzle consisting of the two-symbol string MU. The MU-puzzle is
a problem in formal systems. The puzzle asks whether the string MIU can be derived from the string
MU by using the following three rules. The MU-puzzle is an imaginary puzzle that I will use to
introduce the notions of strings, rules, and derivations. The MU-puzzle is a simple puzzle with
only two letters, M and U. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle that is impossible to solve. The MU-puzzle is
a puzzle that is the basis for the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle that is discussed in detail
in the first chapter of this book.

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU. The MU-puzzle
consists of a string of letters consisting of M, U, and I. The MU-puzzle is an exercise in
changing strings according to specific rules. The goal is to discover, through experimentation and
intuition, whether the MU-puzzle can be "solved" by applying the given rules. The MU-puzzle
provides a concrete example of a formal system, abstract enough to illustrate the concepts of
formal systems, such as strings, rules, algorithms, and the nature of meaning.

The MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal system. It consists of a set of symbols (M, U, I)
and a set of rules for manipulating those symbols. The goal is to determine whether the string MIU
can be derived from the axiom MU using the given rules. The rules are:
1. If a string ends with an I, you can add a U to it.
2. If a string has three consecutive I's, you can replace those three I's with a single U.
3. If a string has two consecutive U's, you can replace them with an I.
The MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal system. It consists
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter alphabet, M and U, and four rules of
manipulation. The MU-puzzle is the problem of getting from the string MI to MU using only the
four rules. The MU-puzzle is a variation of the MU puzzle discussed in my book Gödel, Escher,
Bach: an Eternal Golden Braid. The MU-puzzle is a way to explore issues of meaning, definition,
and the nature of self-reference.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is an example of a formal
system. The problem is to see how meaning can be defined in such a system. The example is used
to explore the concepts of "formal" vs. "meaningful" and "definition".
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The third chapter is an exploration of the relationship between
figure and ground in the context of mathematics and thought. The example used is the MU-puzzle.
The concepts of figure and ground are used to reflect on the nature of meaning and definition.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. The fourth chapter is an exploration of
the concepts of consistency and completeness in formal systems. The MU-puzzle is used to
demonstrate the ideas of consistency and completeness
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A two-part version of the MU-puzzle is presented. The MU-puzzle is
a simple example of a formal system, which I use to explain the nature of formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. A "two-part invention" is presented, in the style of Bach's "Two-Part
Invention." The main theme is a simple, clear-cut problem that is almost impossibly difficult to
solve, as it seems to go to the heart of the nature of formal systems. The problem is presented, but
not fully solved in the limited time available.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is used to give an example of how
it is possible to think about meaning in mathematics, and how one can define the semantics of a
formal system.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria that the Tortoise brings to Achilles, asking him to
solve the MU-puzzle. The story of the MU-puzzle is told, with the Tortoise trying to make it as
easy as possible, and Achilles trying to make it as hard as possible.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The concepts of figure and ground in the MU-puzzle are discussed.
The Tortoise tries to get Achilles to focus on

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader started. It is a
metrical puzzle that also turns out to be a labyrinthine exploration of the notion of meaning.
The MU-puzzle is a contrived example that seems at first to have nothing to do with meaning, but
through various excursions, the MU-puzzle will turn out to be a kind of "labyrinth" which will
lead us to some profound concepts.
...

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a formal system. The MU-puzzle consists of
strings of letters consisting of M, I, and U. The MU-puzzle is a completely made-up puzzle,
which I will use for a number of different purposes throughout the book. The puzzle is to figure out
how to get from the starting string MI to the string MU by using certain rules. The MIU puzzle was
invented by the logician McCarthy. The puzzle is a wonderful example of a simple formal system,
and I use it to illustrate the concept of strings and rules.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a very simple system to
examine, but it is a system that is similar to the more complicated systems that come up in
mathematics and in computer science. The MU-puzzle is an example of a formal system: a set of
strings and rules for manipulating those strings. The puzzle is to figure out how to get from MI to
MU using the rules. The puzzle is a good way to introduce the concept of meaning and form in
mathematics.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. In the MU-puzzle, the string MU is a goal that we are trying
to reach. The MU-puzzle is similar
---

puzzle. The MU puzzle is a well-known exercise in mathematical logic. The MU puzzle asks whether
a string can be derived from the axiom in a given system. The MU puzzle is a good example of a
formal system, and it's particularly suitable for the purposes of illustrating the concepts of
formal systems, consistency, completeness, and decidability.
The MU puzzle is presented in detail, along with the problem of trying to derive the string MU
from the axiom MIU using the two rules of production. The MU puzzle is a simple yet powerful
example that introduces the reader to the concepts of formal systems, consistency, completeness, and
decidability.
The MU puzzle is discussed in detail, and the reader is invited to attempt to solve it. The MU
puzzle is a good example of a formal system, and it's particularly suitable for the purposes of
illuminating the concepts of formal systems, consistency, completeness, and decidability.

Chapter XII: Minds and Thoughts 369
Aria with Diverse Variations 391

Edifying Thoughts of a Tobacco Smoker 480
Chapter XVI: Self-Ref and Self-Rep 495
The Magn fierab, Indeed 549

SHRDLU, Toy of Man's Designing 586

Six-Part Ricercar 720

Bibliography 746
Credits 757
Index 759
Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple yet profound puzzle: what can be done with the MU puzzle?
This is a puzzle about strings, recursion, and formal systems. The MU-puzzle is a good example of
how we think about systems: what can we achieve within given constraints. It is a useful way to
approach the larger issues in this book.
Two-Part Invention. In this two-part piece, the Tortoise and Achilles explore the concept of
meaning and form in mathematics. The discussion starts with an intriguing puzzle (the MU-puzzle) and
gradually leads to an examination of the nature of mathematical meaning. The reader is taken through
the process of how mathematical statements can be interpreted in different ways, leading to
different meanings. This is a key part of the book and sets the stage for the discussion of formal
systems.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise discuss
the MU-puzzle. The Tortoise presents the puzzle, and Achilles tries to solve it. Their conversation
leads to a discussion of formal systems and the nature of mathematical truth. The Tortoise argues that
there are limits to what can be achieved within any formal system, while Achilles is more optimistic.
This is a key part of the book
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A Simple Formal System. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet
powerful formal system, which I use to explain the concept of formal systems, axioms, rules of
inference, and the idea of formal proofs. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle in which the goal is to
transform the string "MI" into "MU" using given transformation rules. It is a great example of a
purely syntactic system, with no meaning. It helps the reader understand the nature of formal
systems, axiomatic systems, and the process of deduction. The MU-puzzle is a good example of
why such systems are called "formal" because they deal with symbols without any inherent meaning.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a good example of a purely
syntactic system, with no meaning. However, once a meaning is assigned to the symbols, the system
can take on an entirely different and meaningful form. This leads to a discussion of the relationship
between meaning and form in mathematics. The discussion also covers the nature of mathematical
truth, the role of axioms, and the importance of formal systems in capturing mathematical truth.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle also leads to
---
