Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules,
and derivations. It is a good example of a simple formal system, which resembles the MIU
puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a good example of a system that is consistent but not complete.
The MU-puzzle was first introduced by Douglas Hofstadter in his book GEB, and I will be using
it throughout the book to illustrate various concepts.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise explore the concept of
recursion. They discuss how to describe recursion in a formal system, and how such a system can
be used to generate complex patterns and behaviors.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the concepts of
formal systems, consistency, completeness, and the relationship between meaning and form. They
discuss the MU-puzzle and its implications for the nature of mathematical systems. They also
discuss the concept of the "Gödel number," which is a way of encoding mathematical statements into
numbers, and how this can be used to show the limitations of formal systems.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A musical piece that is written in a way that mirrors the
 conversation between Achilles
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Fragment of a much larger system. The MU-puzzle consists of
strings of Ms and Us. The MIU puzzle starts with the string MI and one single production rule: 
If a string begins with MU, you can add a U. The puzzle asks whether MU can be obtained through
application of the rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of Gödel's famous Theorem.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. A discussion of the MU-puzzle as an example of
how meaning can be separated from form. The Tortoise and Achilles, with their "overshooting" of
their own Form, end up taking on asplodges of meaning. The discussion then shifts to the 
separation of meaning and form in mathematics, leading into the heart of the MU-puzzle.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The third part of the first triad. The third part of the MU-puzzle.
The discussion of figure and ground leads to a discussion of the relationship between the MU-puzzle
and the MU-puzzle.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. The fourth part of the first triad. The
MU-puzzle as an example of a formal system. Consistency, completeness, and
---

whether the system can derive the string MU.

impressed by the power of formal systems to make Zeno's paradoxes disappear. The system MU is
presented, and the puzzle is given: Can MU derive the string MU?
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is used to discuss formal systems
and the question of meaning in mathematics. The MU-puzzle is given a detailed analysis, and it's
shown how formal systems can represent aspects of mathematics.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise, discussing
the MU-puzzle. The discussion is a precursor to the first formal systems and the MU-puzzle is
given a detailed analysis.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The concept of figure and ground is discussed, with the Tortoise
trying to explain the relationship between figure and ground. Achilles, being a plodding mechanist,
does not understand the subtleties of this distinction.

ground,

Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Fragment of a Formal System. MU puzzle: To decide, for any
string consisting of M and U, whether it can be derived from MU via the given rules. This is a
good example of a simple formal system. The MU-puzzle is a classic puzzle in logic and recursion.
The MU puzzle is stated. Some examples are given. The puzzle is to determine whether 'MU' can
be derived from 'MI' using the rules: 1. Add a U at the end: MI→MII. 2. Double the string: MII→MIIII. 3. If a string ends with III, replace it with a U: MIIII→MIIU. 4. If a string ends with U, you can remove it: MU→M.
The MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal system with a simple set of rules.
The MU-puzzle is an example of a formal system. It is a good example of a formal system. It is a
good example of a formal system. It is a good example of a formal system.
The MU-puzzle is an example of a formal system. It is a good example of a formal system.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem.
Two-Part Invention. A "tune" for two voices. It is in the style of Bach's canons. The
tune is presented as a problem: "What happens if we try to carry out the MU-strings' axiom
and rules of inference?" The title of the Invention is "The MU-puzzle" since it seems to involve
the MU-puzzle. The problem is: Starting from MU, can you get to a different string using the
given rules? Or is MU a "perpetual string" that never can be "perpetually transformed"?
The MU-puzzle is a variation of the MIU puzzle of Lewis Carroll. The MU-puzzle is a
formal system where MU is the only axiom, and the only allowed rules are: a) If a string ends with
I, you can add a U to it. b) If a string ends with U, you can insert a U before it. c) If a string
contains III, you can replace that with a U. d) If a string contains UU, you can remove them.
The MU-puzzle is a variation of the MIU puzzle of Lewis
---

Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle to illustrate the notion of "strings" as formal
systems. The MU-puzzle consists of a single axiom and three rules of production. The question is
whether MU can be derived from the axiom.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention AABAABAAB is discussed in the context of
musical form. Then the two-part Invention is that of the Dialogues, in which Achilles and the
Tortoise are the main participants. Achilles is a mathematician, the Tortoise a Crab. Their dialogue
revolves around a MU-puzzle, leading to a discussion of the MU-puzzle and its relation to
Gödel's Theorem.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle to get the reader to start thinking about the nature
of formal systems. It is called MU-puzzle. The puzzle asks: Starting from the string "MI", can you
reach "MU" using only the four given rules of string manipulation? The MU-puzzle is a simple
example of a formal system, and I use it to explain such concepts as strings, rules of inference,
axioms, systems, and deduction. The reader is asked to work through the MU-puzzle on the
spiral of thought leading to an explanation of the MU-puzzle's relevance to the larger issues in the
book.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore some
tortuous issues in the foundations of mathematics, trying to get to the bottom of the question: What
are numbers? What are they made of? The main focus here is on the concept of 'form' in mathematics.
The discussion is carried forward into the next chapter, where we see how the Tortoise and Achilles
continue their quest for understanding the meaning of form in mathematics.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. Here, the Tortoise and Achilles are concerned with how
certain concepts can be "understood" by the human mind.
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU. It consists of a
string of letters M and U, and some rules for manipulating it. The MU-puzzle is to figure out if
M -> MU is provable in MU. The MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal system, and we
discuss how to approach such systems. We also discuss the idea of "strings" and how to manipulate
them. We also touch upon the concept of "meaning" and how it can be assigned to formal systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal
system, and we discuss how to approach such systems. We also discuss the idea of "strings" and
how to manipulate them. We also touch upon the concept of "meaning" and how it can be assigned
to formal systems.

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter alphabet, M and U, and four production rules
that transform strings of M and U. The puzzle is to see whether you can get the string MU from
the axiom MI, using just the production rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of the more
general problem of formal systems, which are the basis of Mathematical Logic and of Computer
Science. The MU-puzzle is given a thorough treatment, including the complete enumeration of
all possible MU strings through levels. The puzzle is discussed in detail, with the MU-puzzle
being a microcosm of formal systems, and the problem of levels in formal systems. The MU-puzzle is
posed, and the reader is asked to solve it.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the MU-puzzle
and its relation to the concepts of meaning and form in mathematics. Achilles, as the swift thinker,
outsmarts the Tortoise in several ways. The discussion ranges from the nature of mathematics to
the concept of formal systems. The MU-puzzle is shown to be a model for the kind of problems
that arise in the foundations of mathematics. The reader is led to see how formal systems can be
both restrictive and yet have the
---

throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the

ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a Postulate System, called MU, in which
strings of letters are transformed according to certain rules. The MU-puzzle is about trying to
prove a certain statement within the MU-system. The puzzle is a good example of how formal
reasoning works. It is a very simple system, yet it mirrors many aspects of the more complex
systems that come later in the book.
Three-Part Invention. The second part of the first three-part set. It starts with some background
about the MU-puzzle, then goes on to talk about the meaning and form in mathematics. The
tortoise and Achilles, once more, give their impressions on how the MU-puzzle works.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles, with some
impressions on how formal systems can be given meaning. The discussion is about how formal
reasoning works and how it relates to human understanding. It also discusses how mathematics is
not just about symbols, but about concepts and ideas.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of a "formal
system". MU-moves: The MU-puzzle is a good example of a simple formal system. In the MU-puzzle,
we start with the string "MI" and try to reach "MU" by applying certain rules. The MU-puzzle is a
good example of a formal system, and it helps in understanding the concept of formal systems, of
strings, and the role of rules in generating new strings.

I think you can understand this MU-puzzle. Let me explain. The MU-puzzle is a simple formal system
that consists of an alphabet of just two letters: M and I. The system has three rules:

1. If a string ends with I, you can add a U at the end.
2. If a string starts with M, you can add a U at the beginning.
3. If a string contains the substring III, you can replace it with a U.

The goal is to start with MI and reach MU. How? Let's see.

Start: MI

Goal: MU

Rule 1: Can't apply because the string doesn't end with I.

Rule 2: Can't apply because the string doesn't start with M.

Rule 
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle that somehow relates to everything.
MU puzzle is an exercise in formal systems, and I use it to explain how mathematical systems are
constructed. MU puzzle leads into the idea of strings and rules of transformation. The MU-puzzle
is presented as an example of a simple formal system, and the concept of well-formed formulas in
mathematical and logical systems is introduced.

Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part inventions are discussed in the context of the Two-Part
Invention dialogue. The first part is an example of a "magnificent" fugue, and the second part is an
example of a "magnificent" canon. The dialogue draws upon the structure of these musical works.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the MU-puzzle
and the MU-puzzle's relation to meaning in mathematics. The concept of meaning is tied to the
formal system in which the strings are given meaning. The Tortoise argues that meaning is a property
of the system, while the Achilles thinks that meaning is inherent in the system. This leads to a
debate about whether mathematical systems are "meaningless" (like chess) or if they have inherent
meaning.

Son
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle. Let's see: M and U. The puzzle is to find
ways to get from M to MU, using certain rules. The MU-puzzle is a minimal version of the
problem that led to the book. It illustrates the idea of formal systems, as developed in the next
chapter.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part Invention I. The first part is written in counterpoint, the
second part is written in a fugue. It is a nice example of the musical concepts discussed in the
previous chapter.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question: What is Meaning? The discussion
starts with mathematics as a language, and the difference between mathematics and formal
mathematics. The formalists are discussed, and the notion of meaning in mathematics is contrasted
with formal manipulations.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria written by Achilles, in which he is accompanied by
the Tortoise. The Aria is a statement by Achilles, and the responses are from the Tortoise and
the Crab. The point is that the Tortoise is trying to out-Achilles Achilles. The responses are
based on the MU-puzzle, as discussed in the previous chapter.
Chapter
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe with one symbol and two production rules, this
puzzle is used to explain the concept of formal systems. The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a
formal system, a set of rules for string manipulation, which we will be dealing with in depth later.
The MU-puzzle consists of a single axiom: MU, and two production rules: 
1. If a string ends with 'U', you can add a 'U' on top of it.
2. If a string ends with ' MU', you can insert ' MU' in the middle of the string.

The MU-puzzle is a minimal example of a formal system, illustrating the idea of a system with
axioms and rules. The puzzle is to see whether certain strings can be derived from the axiom using
the production rules. For example, can you derive the string 'MUltiple Us'?

Wait, no, that's not possible because MU is the starting point. Let's try to see if we can get 'MUU'?
Yes, by applying rule 1 to MU, since it ends with U, we add another U, making MUU.

Similarly, from MUU, can we apply rule 2? MUU ends with U, so rule
---


---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle to begin with. I have a string of letters consisting
of M, I, and U. The MU-puzzle is about the possibility of getting from MU to various
strings through certain rules. This puzzle is a very simple version of Gödel's Theorem. The
Prelude is a short Bach piece that sets the stage for the MU-puzzle.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. Meaning is in the eye of the beholder; the
Formalists have it that meaning is irrelevant, that Mathematics is a meaningless game played with
strings of symbols. I try to refute that viewpoint. The Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles is
a piece that is a little bit of Bach's theme, with some mathematical overtones, which I use to
discuss how we recognize patterns and the like.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The concept of figure and ground is discussed, with reference to
Escher's prints. The Contracrostipunctus is a piece that I wrote which is a kind of "figure and
ground" puzzle.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. Consistency and completeness are
defined, leading to an explanation of Gödel's Theorem. The Little Harmonic L
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules
and derivations. It is a "toy" version of the MU-puzzle, which is a small example of a formal
system. The MU-puzzle is a string rewriting system, and the question is whether the string MU can
be derived from the string M. The puzzle is an example of a formal system, and the MU--canonical
system is a set of rules for deriving new strings from existing ones. The MU-puzzle is a small
example of a formal system, and the MU-canonical system is a set of rules for deriving new strings
from existing ones. The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a formal system, and the MU-canonical
system is a set of rules for deriving new strings from existing ones. The MU-puzzle is a simple
example of a formal system, and the MU-canonical system is a set of rules for deriving new strings
from existing ones. The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a formal system, and the MU-canonical
system is a set of rules for deriving new strings from existing ones. The MU-puzzle is a simple
example of a formal system, and the MU-canonical system is a set
---

Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the puzzle is to find out whether
the MU string can be derived within the system. The MU-puzzle is a very simple self-referential
system. It is a good example for explaining the concept of a formal system, and the nature of
metamathematics.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise decide to explore logic, which
leads to the discussion of propositional logic, and then to the propositional calculus. Then, in
order to get a feeling for the power and charm of mathematical logic, we discuss the MU-puzzle
and the so-called MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a good example for explaining the concept of a
formal system, and the nature of metamathematics.

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A two-part puzzle: the MU-puzzle consists of the MU string, and
the four rules for manipulating it. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound example of a formal
system. The MU-puzzle illustrates the idea of a formal system, which is a set of axioms and rules
of inference. The MU-puzzle consists of the MU string, and the four rules for manipulating it.
The MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound example of a formal system. The MU-puzzle illustrates
the idea of a formal system, which is a set of axioms and rules of inference.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a two-part puzzle: the MU
string, and the four rules for manipulating it. The MU-puzzle consists of the MU string, and the
four rules for manipulating it. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound example of a formal system.
The MU-puzzle illustrates the idea of a formal system, which is a set of axioms and rules of
inference. The MU-puzzle consists of the MU string, and the four rules for manipulating it. The
MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound example of a formal system. The MU-puzzle illustrates the
idea
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem. The MU-puzzle
asks whether, from the string "MU", one can derive the string "MIU" using four production rules
that manipulate strings. It is a simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem. The MU-puzzle
is a way of "proving" the MU-puzzle's inability to derive MIU from MU, by the definition of the
production rules.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part Invention is a set of two variations. Each part is a
counterpoint: one part is a variation on a theme presented by the King, the other part is a variation
on a theme presented by the Queen. The two-part Invention is similar to the three-part Invention,
but without the third part.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a way of "proving" the MU-puzzle's
inability to derive MIU from MU, by the definition of the production rules. The MU-puzzle is a
way of "proving" the MU-puzzle's inability to derive MIU from MU, by the definition of the
production rules. The MU-puzzle is a
---

You are a highly advanced AI specialized in scientific and philosophical analysis. Based on the following text, produce a JSON object with the following keys:

  - 'summary': Bullet points summarizing the content concisely.
  - 'key_topics': A list of the main topics extracted from the content.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle, which I use to illustrate the concept of formal
systems. MU-puzzle consists of the symbols M, U, and the two rules: (1) If a string ends with an
M, you can add a U to the end. (2) If a string ends with an MU, you can insert a U between them.
The puzzle is to figure out whether, given an initial string, you can reach a certain target string. It's a
simple puzzle, but it has profound implications for the nature of formal systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This chapter discusses the notion of formal
systems and their relationship to mathematics, as well as the concept of meaning. It includes a
detailed discussion of the MU-puzzle, and how it relates to the broader concepts.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The concept of figure and ground is discussed in terms of
Gödel's incompleteness theorems, Escher's prints, and the human brain. The idea is that any
formal system is inherently incomplete, and that there is a separation between the "system" and the
"world" outside of it.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. This chapter discusses the
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the reader is asked to
perform some simple manipulations to gain experience in formal reasoning.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise explore the concept of
infinity, which is then tied to the concept of self-reference. The dialogue serves to foreshadow the
later discussion of recursive structures and the MU-puzzle.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question of how formal systems can capture
the meaning of statements is discussed. The MU-puzzle is presented as a particular example, and
the reader is asked to solve it.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. The Achilles' Tortoise, plus a few other characters, perform
music based on the MU-puzzle. The musical pieces are written at a level that is intermediate
between that of a professional musician and that of a college student. They should not be
understood by someone who hasn't studied music since high school, but they should be
understandable to everyone. The story is written in such a way that the reader can understand
the connection between the pieces and the MU-puzzle.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The concepts of figure and ground in the plane, in painting and
the music
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A Simple Formal System. The MU-puzzle is a simple, yet
powerful, system that illustrates the concepts of formal systems, meaning, and deduction. The
puzzle is to start with the string "MI" and see if you can reach "MU" using only the given rules. The
puzzle is a gateway to understanding the nature of formal systems, axioms, and rules of inference.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a gateway to understanding
the nature of formal systems, axioms, and rules of inference. We examine the MU-puzzle, the
propositions and theorems of the MU-system, and the relationship between meaning and form in
mathematics. The discussion includes the concepts of formal systems, the distinction between syntax
and semantics, and the idea that in mathematics, meaning can be assigned arbitrarily.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle is a gateway to understanding the concept of
figure and ground in mathematics. We examine the MU-puzzle, the concepts of figure and ground, and
the relationship between them in mathematical systems. The discussion includes the concepts of figure
and ground, and how they relate to the MU-puzzle and formal systems.
Chapter IV: Consistency
---

Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem is presented in
this chapter, which is based on an imaginary computer called the ‘Turing machine’. The MU-puzzle
is a puzzle in which the only allowable moves are to append 'III' to a string of 'M's, or to
replace 'U' in a string of 'MUs' with 'UUM's. The goal is to get from 'MI' to 'MU'. It is shown how
the MU-puzzle relates to the concept of formal systems, and how it relates to the idea of
undecidable propositions in mathematics.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The concept of 'formal' vs. 'content' in mathematics
is discussed. The MU-puzzle is used to illustrate how it is possible to have an exact formal
system that is also rich and meaningful. The idea of 'meaning' in mathematics is presented as being
dependent on the formal system in which it is expressed. The concept of 'recursive' vs. 'non-recursive'
sets is introduced. The relationship between formal systems and human understanding is
discussed. The idea of 'formal systems as models' is presented.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The
---


---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings in
formal systems. The MU-puzzle consists of a single axiom (MI) and four rules of production, and
the question is whether "MU" can be derived from the axiom. The MU-puzzle is a variant of the
Lucas’ “Waterfall” puzzle. I give the solution in detail, and also explain how to approach such
puzzles.
The MU-puzzle is a variant of the Lucas’ “Waterfall” puzzle.
The MU-puzzle consists of a single axiom (MI) and four rules of production:
1. xI → xIU
2. Mx → MxI
3. xIII → xU
4. Ux → UxU
I give the solution in detail, and also explain how to approach such puzzles.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This chapter discusses the MU-puzzle as an
intuitive approach to the problem of meaning and form in mathematics. It is also a warm-up to the
more complex puzzle that comes later in the book: the MU-puzzle is a variant of the Lucas’
“Waterfall” puzzle.
The MU-puzzle is a variant of the Lucas’ “Waterfall
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A Simple Example. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound
example of a formal system. It consists of the two axioms: M -> MI, and MI ->MII. The
third rule is that whenever a theorem has a III in it, you can delete a III. The MU-puzzle is to
prove M -> MU. It's impossible, and the MU-puzzle lies at the heart of this book. I use this as
an introductory example to explain the nature of formal systems, the axiomatic method, and
the role of meaning in mathematics.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a microcosm of the way
mathematics and formal systems work. It consists of symbols that are given meaning by the user.
But once the user has defined the meaning of the symbols, the system of theorems is completely
determined. Despite the lack of intrinsic meaning, the system has surprising and beautiful
properties. It can be mapped to other systems: for example, the MU-puzzle can be thought of as
a string rewriting system. The MU-puzzle is an example of a purely syntactic system: it
concerns only patterns of symbols, not their meanings. Formal systems can
---


---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader started. The MU-puzzle is
given by Hofstadter in his book Gödel, Escher, Bach: a puzzle involving strings of letters, and
specifically, the transformations between them. The MU-puzzle is introduced, and the reader is
posed the question: Is the string MIW a theorem of the MU-puzzle?

Three-Part Invention. The second Invention is a set of three pieces that present the MU-puzzle
from different angles, and also introduce some of the ideas of the first Chapter.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the question:
Is mathematics more like a game, or is it more like a story? The debate centers on the nature of
meaning in mathematics, and how formal systems can model reality.

Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A musical piece that the Tortoise and Achilles discuss in
depth. The piece is a series of variations on a theme, each variation representing different aspects
of the MU-puzzle and the nature of mathematical meaning.

Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the concept of figure and ground,
analogous to the concepts of meaning and form.

Contracrostip
---


---

requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, MU, and the question of
whether the string MU can be derived within the system. The MU-puzzle is a recursive puzzle
that has as its aim to explore the concept of self-reference. The puzzle is given by a
set of rules, and the MU-puzzle is an example of a Postitive Propositional Calculus. The MU-puzzle
leads to a discussion of the MU-puzzle: meaning and form in mathematics, and the problem of
whether meaning can be separated from form.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a two-dimensional puzzle that
has as its aim to explore the concept of self-reference. The MU-puzzle is given by a set of
rules, and the MU-puzzle is an example of a Positive Propositional Calculus. The MU-puzzle
leads to a discussion of the MU-puzzle: meaning and form in mathematics, and the problem of
whether meaning can be separated from form.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle is a two-dimensional puzzle that has as its aim to
explore the concept of self-reference. The MU-puzzle is given by a set of rules, and the MU-puzzle
is an example of

of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe with a few axioms and rules, and some simple
strings. The puzzle is to find out whether the MU string can be derived using the given rules. The
problem is a good example of a "good" logical puzzle.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is discussed. It is a set of two complementary
fragments that make up a more complex musical piece. The two-part invented by Bach is discussed,
and how it relates to the concept of self-reference in the book.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The concept of "meaning" and "form" in
mathematics is discussed. This is a key part of the book. The discussion is lengthy and covers
many aspects of formal systems, such as the MU-puzzle. The idea of the "mathematical shell" is
introduced. This concept is important in understanding how formal systems can represent
different kinds of "shells" or "skins" of meaning.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A four-part musical piece that is written for a single
player. The story is told in the text, and the musical piece is presented. It is a central theme of
the book. Achilles and the Tortoise are the two
---

and Related Systems 438

The Magn fierab, Indeed 549

Six-Part Ricercar 720

Bibliography 746
Credits 757
Index 759
Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Fragment of a Formal System. The MU-puzzle consists of
strings of M's and U's, and transformation rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of the
problem that led to the development of meta-mathematics and the idea of formal systems. This
puzzle illustrates the concept of "strings" and "rules of transformation" and the quest for an "axiomatic
system" that can prove all true statements within the system.

In the MU-puzzle, the goal is to transform the string "MI" into "MU" using the given rules. The
rules are:

1. If a string ends with an I, you can add a U to the end.
2. If a string has III in it, you can replace that III with a U.
3. If a string ends with an U, you can double the last symbol before it.
4. If a string has UU somewhere in it, you can remove them.

The MU-puzzle is a simple version of the problem that led to the development of meta-mathematics
and the idea of formal systems. This puzzle illustrates the concept of "strings" and "rules of
transformation" and the quest for an "axiomatic system" that
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived mathematical puzzle. The MU-puzzle consists of a
string of letters, M and U and I. The MU-puzzle is the puzzle of getting from MI to MU
using certain rules. The puzzle is an example of a formal system, a minimal system to explain
something. The MU-puzzle is a very simple yet profound example of self-reference and
meta-reasoning, and is used as a vehicle to explain Gödel's Theorem.

Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part inventions: contrapunctus, which are fugues that are
played forwards and backwards. In the second part, the story of the invention that gave rise to
the fugue is told. The second fugue is the "Ant Fugue".

Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question "What is Mathematics?" is discussed
from a variety of points of view: Platonism, Formalism, Intuitionism. The MU-puzzle is revisited,
and the notions of "meaning" and "form" in mathematics are discussed. The puzzle is used to
examine the different views of mathematics.

Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Achilles, a hero of the Trojan war, is the subject of a
song
---

throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules,
and derivations. The MU-puzzle is a good example of how we can make the notion of formal
system precise. The MU-puzzle is the smallest possible system that can be used as a vehicle for
explaining the important concepts of formal systems, such as strings, rules, and derivations.
The MU-puzzle consists of an alphabet with just two symbols: M and U. The puzzle is to find a
way to derive the string UU from the string MU, using just the two rules given: Rule 1: If you
have a string that ends with an M, you can add a U to the end of it. Rule 2: If you have a string
that contains three Us in a row, you can replace them with a single M. The MU-puzzle is a good
example of how we can make the notion of formal system precise. The MU-puzzle is the smallest
possible system that can be used as a vehicle for explaining the important concepts of formal systems,
such as strings, rules, and derivations.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter alphabet, M and U. Four rules are given for
producing strings in the system. It is a puzzle to figure out which strings can be produced.
The MU-puzzle is a contrived system in which the MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound example of
a formal system. It is used to explain the nature of formal systems, of which mathematics is a
part. In the MU-puzzle, the goal is to figure out whether M can be transformed into MU. It is a
puzzle to figure out how to get from M to MU, and it is a model of a formal system. It is a
fundamental example used to explain the nature of formal systems, of which mathematics is a part.

The MU-puzzle is a contrived system in which the MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound example of
a formal system. It is used to explain the nature of formal systems, of which mathematics is a part.
The MU-puzzle is a contrived system in which the MU-puzzle is a simple yet profound example of
a formal system. It is used to explain the nature of formal systems, of which mathematics is a part.
The MU-puzzle is a contrived system in which the MU-puzzle
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe with strings of letters M and U. The MU-puzzle is
about trying to reach a certain string through simple string rewriting rules. It is a simple yet
powerful model of computation at its core. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle about the nature of
mechanical computation and the nature of mathematical proof.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the nature of
meaning and form in mathematics, particularly the question of whether mathematics is discovered or
invented. They discuss the MU-puzzle in detail, and how it relates to the nature of mathematical
truth. They also introduce the concept of formal systems, and the idea of formalization of
mathematics.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the relationship between figure
and ground in mathematical and philosophical terms. They explore the idea that certain concepts
are "figure" and others are "ground," and how this distinction relates to the nature of mathematical
and logical systems.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the
foundations of geometry and logic, discussing the concepts of consistency and completeness in
mathematical systems. They also touch on the relationship between geometry and logic
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter alphabet, M and U, and four rules of
manipulation. The MU-puzzle is to figure out why the MU-string cannot be derived from the
starting string MU.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is based on the idea of contrapunctus, that is, a
counterpoint in music. A contrapunctus in the musical sense is a musical phrase or theme
played against another, which is exactly analogous to the concept of recursion in logic and math.
The two-part invention is a musical version of the idea of recursion.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The problem of how formal systems come to
express something meaningful, the issue of meaning and form in mathematics. This leads to
Gödel's Theorem, which states that in any formal system, there are propositions which are
true but cannot be proved. The significance of Gödel's Theorem in mathematics and philosophy is
discussed.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Achilles, a hero from Greek mythology, is the hero of a
sonata. The story of Achilles is given, and the musical work is played. The discussion relates the
sonata to the ideas presented in the preceding chapter. The story
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a formal system, which is a mathematical
puzzle: it consists of a string of letters, and some rules for "manipulating" it. The MU-puzzle is
a contrived one, just to see how a formal system can work. The MU-puzzle is a string of letters M and U, and the puzzle is to see how to get from MU to MiU using four rules. The puzzle illustrates the concepts of "theorem", "axioms", and "rules of inference". The MU-puzzle is a very simple version of the MU-puzzle in Hofstadter's Gödel, Escher, Bach, and is given here in the context of explaining the notions of formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is based on the concept of the "choices" or "the
freedom" of the mind. The story is about a king who wants to give a musical performance, but is
stuck with only two themes. The story involves the concept of the "freedom" of the mind and how it
can "chooses" to express itself through the sounds. The story also has a moral lesson: that the mind's
freedom is subject to certain constraints, and that
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, which can be used to
introduce the concept of a formal system, and of the distinction between meaning and form. The
MU-puzzle is a puzzle in which one must find a way to get from "MI" to "MU" using only the given
rules. The puzzle is a good example of how formal systems can work, and how they can sometimes
have limitations. It also serves as an analogy for the human mind: how we can be limited by the
rules of our own thinking.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise, in which they try to solve
the MU-puzzle. The dialogue is meant to be both fun and thought-provoking, and to give the reader
a sense of the nature of formal systems. It also serves as an analogy for the human mind: how we can
be limited by the rules of our own thinking.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question of whether meaning can be
defined in purely formal terms is discussed. The MU-puzzle is used as an example, and the
conclusion is that meaning is not purely formal. The discussion then turns to the nature of meaning
in mathematics, and how it is tied
---
