Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader to think about recursion and
formal systems. The MU-puzzle consists of the single string "MI" and the three rules:
1. If a string ends with "I", you can add a "I" at the end.
2. If a string has "M" followed by "I", you can insert "U" after "M".
3. If a string has "III", you can replace it with "U".
The puzzle is: Starting from "MI", can you reach "MU" using these rules? The MU-puzzle is a
famous example in logic and formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is presented as an analogy to the structure of
GEB. The dialogue is between Achilles and the Tortoise, discussing various themes. The Tortoise
points out that every system has a Achilles and a Tortoise: someone who can run faster and
someone who can walk slower.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise tells Achilles that mathematics is not
about plugging numbers into equations; it's about the meaning behind the symbols. Achilles tries to
see through the meaning, but the Tortoise shows that sometimes symbols can be played with
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe of thought in which the MIU puzzle is a simple
example of a formal system. It is here that the concept of strings of letters and the four rules for
manipulating them are introduced. The puzzle is to find a derivation of MU from MI, using only the
four rules. The puzzle is a good example of a formal system, and the MU-puzzle is used to explain
the concept of a formal system.
The MU-puzzle is a tiny universe of thought in which the MIU puzzle is a simple example of a
formal system. It is here that the concept of strings of letters and the four rules for manipulating them
are introduced. The puzzle is to find a derivation of MU from MI, using only the four rules. The
puzzle is a good example of a formal system, and the MU-puzzle is used to explain the concept of a
formal system.

... (continues with more text)

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived (but entirely logical) puzzle that I will use to introduce
the concept of Strings, Rules, and Derivations, that is, the essence of Meta-Mathematics.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise explore some aspects of
numbers and their relationships. The dialogue is written in the spirit of Lewis Caroll, with
tortoise/speed-tortoise, to show the different levels of approachable and of deep into the
subject.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the notions of
Meaning and Form in Mathematics, discussing the MU-puzzle, Zeno's paradoxes, Hilbert's
Formalism, and the MU-puzzle.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A musical sonata that is written in a way that the
numbers of the notes in the successive chords are the same as the succession of MUs in the
MU-puzzle. This is an example of the connection between mathematics and music. The title of
the piece is also "Achilles and the Tortoise," a reference to the famous paradoxes of Zeno.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise discuss
---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a Postulate System. The MU-puzzle is an
example of a simple formal system. A formal system is a set of axioms and rules of inference.
The MU-puzzle consists of the single axiom: MU and two rules: (1) you can add a 'I' after any
letter, (2) you can insert 'II' between any two letters. The puzzle is to find a theorem of this system.
The MU-puzzle is a very simple yet profound example of a formal system. It is a good way to
introduce the idea of formal systems and their properties. The MU-puzzle is also a good way to
introduce the idea of recursion and self-reference in formal systems.

The MU-puzzle is a formal system that consists of the single axiom: MU and two rules: (1) you can add a 'I' after any letter, and (2) you can insert 'II' between any two letters. The puzzle is to find a theorem of this system.

The MU-puzzle is a very simple yet profound example of a formal system. It is a good way to
introduce the idea of formal systems and their properties. The MU-puzzle is also a good way to
introduce

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny toy puzzle to get the reader to start thinking about the nature of
formal systems. The MU-puzzle consists of the single axiom M, and two rules of inference: (1) if
a string ends with an U, you can add an U to it; (2) if a string ends with an N, you can double it.
The goal is to reach the theorem MU from the axiom M.
Two-Part Invention. A two-part variation where Achilles and the Tortoise explore concepts
related to number, specifically the MU-puzzle and the MU-puzzle's relationship to the concept of
formal systems.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria written for the computer. The text is the idea behind
the Aria written for the computer. The computer, unlike the Tortoise, can "understand" the
system it is manipulating. The Tortoise is perplexed by this.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the concepts of
meaning and form in mathematics, discussing the MU-puzzle and the MU-puzzle's relationship to
the concept of formal systems. The discussion also includes the question of whether mathematics is
a discovery or an invention.
Sonata for Unaccompanied
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, MU. The puzzle is to find a
way to derive the string MU from the axioms given. MU consists of the single letter M and the
single letter U. MU puzzle: can the string MU be derived from the axioms? MU puzzle is a
famous example of a formal system that is consistent but not complete. This is an example of
a simple system where certain truths cannot be proven within the system, highlighting the
difference between syntax and semantics.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is used to explore the nature of
meaning in mathematics. The puzzle is given a meaning in terms of numbers and arithmetic, and
the formal system is shown to be equivalent to some formal system of arithmetic. The MU-puzzle
is a good example of how meaning can be assigned to a formal system, and how the formal system
can be given meaning in terms of numbers and arithmetic.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle is used to explore the concept of figure and
ground in mathematics. The MU-puzzle is shown to have two complementary interpretations, one
as a system of numbers and arithmetic, and the other as a system of geometry. The MU-puzzle is

requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived mathematical puzzle. The MU-puzzle consists of the
string "MI" and four possible rules for transforming it. The puzzle is to figure out whether, by
applying these rules, you can reach the string "MU". The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a
problem that is "formally undecidable" - it cannot be solved within the given rules. The MU-puzzle
is introduced by Douglas Hofstadter in his book GEB. It serves as a basis for the discussion of
formal systems, the nature of meaning in mathematics, and the relationship between mathematics and
physics. The MU-puzzle is used to illustrate the idea of "levels of description" and the concept
of "interpretation" in formal systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a contrived mathematical
puzzle. The puzzle is introduced and its rules are explained. Various attempts to solve the puzzle
are made, and the notion of "meaning" in mathematics is explored. The puzzle is used to illustrate
the idea of "formal systems" and the relationship between "form" and "content". The MU-puzzle is
used to show how the concept of "meaning" is both subjective and

  - 'insights': A detailed analysis containing deep scientific and philosophical breakthroughs.
  - 'paper': A formally structured scientific paper that includes the following sections: Title, Abstract, Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, Conclusion, and References.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the reader is asked to
solve a puzzle within it. The system is given by its four production rules, and the puzzle is: Starting
from "MU", is it possible to derive the string "MUG"? The MU-puzzle is a variant of the MIU
system presented in the book.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invented music. The story of the invention is given, and
the two-part invented Music is presented. It is a set of two pieces, one for each part.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A set of three interconnected dialogues that form a
sort of "little harmony" for Achilles and the Tortoise. The title is a pun on Achilles and the Tortoise,
and "unaccompanied" because it's written without any musical notation, just text. The story is
about the Tortoise challenging Achilles to a musical game, but being too slow, and Achilles
having to "perform" by talking, thus bringing out the Fugue and the Crab Canon.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question "What is Meaning?" is central to
the discussion. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss various formal systems and the nature of
meaning
---

formal system, and is used to introduce the concept of "formal systems" and "mechanical
reasoning" as a way of thinking about how minds work. The MU-puzzle also serves as a
prelude to the MU-puzzle as an example of a 'thinking' machine. The MU-puzzle is a stepping stone

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU. It has three
strings: M, I, and U. The MU-puzzle consists of trying to reach the string UUMUUMUUMUIUMUIUIUMU from the
string MI, using just the two rules: a) if you have a string that ends with I, you can add a U to it.
b) if you have a string with three consecutive Is, you can replace them with a single U.

The MU-puzzle is a nice example of a formal system. The puzzle is to see whether it is possible to
reach certain target strings from the starting string MI, using just the two given rules. The MU-puzzle
is a good example of a formal system that is "alive" in the sense that it has the potential for
self-reference and hence for meta-mathematics.

The MU-puzzle: A Simple Formal System. The MU-puzzle is a simple formal system that
consists of strings composed of the letters M, I, and U. The puzzle is to see whether it is possible to
reach the string UUMUUMUUMUIUMUIUIUMU from the starting string MI, using only the two rules: a) if
a
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of the MU-puzzle is presented as an example of
an imaginary alphabet and puzzle. The MU-puzzle consists of the following three rules:
1. The string 'M' can be written at any time.
2. If a string ending with 'I' can be preceded by 'M', then that 'M' can be removed.
3. If a string ending with 'I' can be preceded by 'M', then that 'MI' can be replaced with 'MU'.

The MU-puzzle is a puzzle to find out whether 'MU' can be derived from 'M' using these three
rules. The puzzle is presented as a simple version of the MU-puzzle, and the idea of strings and
rules is used to explain the concept of recursion and formal systems. The MU-puzzle is a
paradigm for exploring the notions of meaning and formal systems.

Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The concept of "meaning" versus "form" in
mathematics is explored. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the difference between the syntactic and
semantic aspects of mathematics, highlighting the tension between the formal manipulation of
symbols and the deeper, more abstract meaning that gives mathematics its power and beauty. The
Paradox of
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle, to begin with, that seems to have no solution.
It is a simple version of Gödel's famous "Gödel Escher Bach" meta-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is
posed: Is the string MU reachable from the string MI, using only certain rules? The MU-puzzle
leads the reader through several levels of abstraction, leading up to an explanation of how
Gödel proved his Incompleteness Theorem. The formalization of symbols and rules, the axioms,
and theorems, the distinction between meaning and form, and the concepts of "Gödel numbers" and
"formal systems" are discussed.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles, after being
introduced to the MU-puzzle, discuss the nature of formal systems. They examine some
propositions of elementary number theory, and attempt to prove theorems. They discuss
metamathematics: the study of mathematical methods themselves. Here, the distinction between
meaning and form is made explicit. The concept of "signs" and "symbols" is discussed. Various
types of formal systems are introduced: "Hilbert's formalism", "Gödel's meta-m
---

  - 'summary': Bullet points summarizing the content concisely.
  - 'key_topics': A list of the main topics extracted from the content.

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings in
mathematics, and the notion of rules for manipulating them. A MU-puzzle consists of the three
strings: M, MU, and the two rules: a) If you can erase a string that ends with MU, you can erase it
to make a string that ends with M. b) If you can append MU to a string that starts with M, you can
do so, making a longer string starting with M and ending with MU.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader to think about the nature
of formal systems. MU-puzzle: The MU-puzzle consists of symbols M and U. The MU-puzzle starts
with M and tries to reach MU. The rules are: 1. If you have a string ending with U, you can add a U.
2. If you have Mx, you can replace x with xU. 3. If you have MUx, you can replace x with xU. 4.
If you have xUUy, you can replace x with xUy. The problem is to determine whether MU is
generable from M according to these rules.

The MU-puzzle is a very simple version of a formal system. It's a puzzle where the reader is asked to
find out whether MU can be obtained from M, given the four rules above.

The MU-puzzle is important because it introduces the concept of a formal system and the idea of
generating theorems within such a system. It serves as a stepping stone towards understanding more
complex systems like those in Gödel's Theorem.

Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the relationship
between meaning and form in mathematics,
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle, which leads to mind-bending ideas about
meaning and formal systems. The MU-puzzle is a minimal version of the MU-uzzle used in the
book to illustrate the idea of a formal system. The MU-puzzle consists of the single axiom "MI"
and four rules of production: a) You can add a "I" to the end of any string on the blackboard.
b) You can double the entire string on the blackboard. c) You can erase a "II" in the middle of any
string. d) You can remove a "III" from the middle of any string. The puzzle asks whether the
string "MU" can be derived from "MI" by applying these rules. The MU-puzzle is a minimal
version of the MU-uzzle used in the book to illustrate the idea of a formal system. The MU-puzzle
has become a classic problem in the study of formal systems and self-reference. The MU-puzzle
has become a classic problem in the study of formal systems and self-reference.

played the MU-puzzle, discuss the MU-puzzle's implications for the concept of meaning and

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter alphabet, M and U. The MU-puzzle is a
completely imaginary puzzle that I just made up to illustrate something I call the MU-puzzle.
Wait, that is not very clear. Let me try again. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle that seems entirely
made up, and yet it is of great importance for understanding the very nature of mathematics.
As much as I can remember from my days in school, the MU-puzzle was introduced to me as a
very simple puzzle in which the player starts with the string MI and is supposed to reach the
string MU by a series of moves of certain types. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle that seems entirely
made up, and yet it is of great importance for understanding the very nature of mathematics.
The MU-puzzle is a puzzle that seems entirely made up, and yet it is of great importance for
understanding the very nature of mathematics.

made up, and yet it is of great importance for understanding the very nature of mathematics.

very simple

Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system. Let me give you the MU-puzzle. It's a
very simple system, with just two axioms and one rule of inference. Let me tell you what they
are. Axiom 1: MU. Axiom 2: If you can derive M X, then you can derive M U X.

Wait, that's all? That's all that's needed? Then the only rule is that if you have M X, you can
get M U X.
Wait, perhaps I'm misunderstanding. Let me rephrase. The MU-puzzle: the MU-puzzle consists of
strings of Ms and Us. The puzzle is: starting from M, can you reach MU?

The MU-puzzle is a contrived system to explore the idea of self-reference and the notion of
meaning within a formal system. The puzzle is: given the two axioms MU and M X implies M U X,
can you derive MU from M? The MU-puzzle is a simple system in which the player must find a way
to get from M to MU, but the rules seem to make it impossible at first glance. It is a
paradigm for the notion of self-reference and the impossibility of certain things in formal
---

ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, MU, which serves as a
toy model for the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a problem in propositional logic. The MU-puzzle
asks whether a particular theorem can be derived from given axioms within the MU system. The
puzzle is a great example of how an abstract system can be given, and how one can approach the
problem of proving or disproving the possibility of deriving a particular theorem. The MU-puzzle
is a key example used in the book to illustrate the concepts of formal systems, self-reference, and
Gödel's incompleteness theorems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a very simple example of a
formal system. The formal system presented is a mathematical one. The MU-puzzle is a
problem in propositional logic. The puzzle is a great example of how an abstract system can be
given, and how one can approach the problem of proving or disproving the possibility of deriving
the theorem MUU. The MU-puzzle is a key example used in the book to illustrate the concepts of
formal systems, self-reference, and Gödel's incompleteness theorems.
Chapter III: Figure and
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader to think about recursion and
formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise try to resolve a riddle posed by
the Tortoise. It is a "small" version of the MU-puzzle, allowing the reader to experience the
problem in depth.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria written by Achilles, based on the MU-puzzle, with
some meta-reflection. It has a profound connection to the MU-puzzle. The problem is an
immediate predecessor of the MU-puzzle. The story of the MU-puzzle is told in detail, and the
player is asked to find a derivation of MU from the given axioms and rules.

Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles is a single-voice piece, which is an exploration of the MU-puzzle.
The player is asked to find a derivation of MU from the given axioms and rules.

Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles: Aria written by Achilles, based on the MU-puzzle, with some
meta-reflection. It has a profound connection to the MU-puzzle. The problem is an immediate
predecessor of the MU-puzzle. The story of the MU
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, which is a "toy" version of
Gödel’s Theorem. MU-puzzle: Can "MU" be derived from "MI" in the MIU system? The
problem is to find out why it's impossible, which is related to the fact that the system is incomplete.
This leads to a discussion of formal systems in mathematics and the role of meaning in mathematics.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle leads to a discussion of what it
means to say that something is true in mathematics-when we say "3+3=6", what does it mean? The
formalists' viewpoint that mathematics is just manipulation of symbols is contrasted with the
Platonic view that mathematical truth is about abstract entities. We discuss the MU-puzzle as an
example of how meaning can be lost when we strip away the forms.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The third part of the three-part invention is presented. The
Prelude presents the first movement, in which the Tortoise and Achilles discuss the figure and
ground for the MU-puzzle. This is a kind of philosophical takeoff point for the book. Achilles
wishes to prove to the Tortoise that he
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter axiom system is given, and the puzzle is to see how
to get to a particular theorem by stringing together rules of production. It is a simple yet
powerful analog for the way real-world axiom systems work. The MU-puzzle is a microcosm of
the entire book. It is a very simple system, with a few axioms and rules, and it is through
this system that the book's central theme is developed.
The MU-puzzle: What is the MU-puzzle? It is a puzzle consisting of a two-letter alphabet (M and
U) and four rules. The goal is to transform the string MI into MU using only these rules. The
puzzle is a great example of a formal system, and it is used to explore the concepts of form and
meaning in mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a microcosm of the entire book. It is a very simple
system, with a few axioms and rules, and it is through this system that the book's central theme
is developed.

First, the summary. It should be bullet points. From the text, I

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived "game" which I use for many purposes throughout the book. It is a
very simple version of the MU-puzzle, which I have found to be an excellent tool for demonstrating
the concepts of Hofstadter's MU- recursive systems and formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part Invention No. 3 is written in a style reminiscent of the
Meditations, and in fact, is inspired by that. The story of the Invention itself is given, as well as
the two-part structure. The discussion of the formal properties of such systems is continued in the
MU-puzzle. The main focus is on the concepts of recursion, reduction, and self-reference.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles, with some
improvisations by Escher, are just starting to get to the bottom of some meta-mathematical
conundrum. The discussion ranges from the nature of mathematics as an artifact to the nature of
mathematics as a mental faculty. The story of the MU-puzzle is given to illustrate the nature of
meaning and form in mathematics.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Achilles, a powerful and somewhat warlike hero, is

---

requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"

interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the concept of
"formal systems", as well as the distinction between "meaning" and "form" in mathematics, are
discussed. The puzzle is then presented, and the reader is asked to solve it.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is based on the idea of theMU-puzzle. The
Tortoise and Achilles play a game based on this puzzle. It is a simple game, but it brings out the
power of recursion. The game is presented as a sort of "musical offering" in the style of Bach.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Achilles, a powerful warrior, is presented as a
supremely skilled musician. He plays a sonata, which is a simple theme. The sonata is presented as
a series of variations, each variation being an exploration of different aspects of the theme. The
sonata is presented as a "musical offering" in the style of Bach.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is used to explain the
distinction between "meaning" and "form" in mathematics. The puzzle is presented as a formal
system, and the reader is asked to solve it. The

Chapter XIV: On Formally Undecidable Propositions of TNT
and Related Systems 438
Birthday Cantatatata ... 461
Chapter XV: Jumping out of the System 465
Edifying Thoughts of a Tobacco Smoker 480
Chapter XVI: Self-Ref and Self-Rep 495
The Magn fierab, Indeed 549
Chapter XVII: Church, Turing, Tarski, and Others 559
SHRDLU, Toy of Man's Designing 586
Chapter XVIII: Artificial Intelligence: Retrospects 594
Contrafactus 633
Chapter XIX: Artificial Intelligence: Prospects 641
Sloth Canon 681
Chapter XX: Strange Loops, Or Tangled Hierarchies 684
Six-Part Ricercar 720
Notes 743
Bibliography 746
Credits 757
Index 759
Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the puzzle is to find out whether
M can be derived from the axioms of the system. MU-puzzle is a simple version of GEB, and
GEB is a simple version of EGB. The MU-puzzle is given in Escher’s drawing. The MU-puzzle is
a good way to start, because it introduces the idea of a formal system, and hence abstractly
represents the MU-pondered system of the GEB book. The formal system is presented in a way
that is easy to understand, and the puzzle is to find out whether M can be derived.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise explore some aspects of
mathematical and logical systems. They discuss the MU-puzzle, and also the concept of formal
systems, meaning, and form in mathematics. The Tortoise presents the MU-puzzle to Achilles, who
tries to solve it. The discussion delves into the nature of formal systems, the difference between
meaning and form in mathematics, and the idea of recursion. The dialogue is a precursor to the
MU-puzzle, and it also introduces the concept of self-reference and the MU-puzzle is a good

---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Fragment of Formal Thought. This chapter discusses the MU-puzzle,
which is a simple example of a formal system. It is a contrived language consisting of the
strings of M, U, and I. The MU-puzzle is an example of a Postulate System, with three
axioms and one rule of inference. The puzzle is to see whether MU can be derived from these
postulates. It is a simple yet profound example of the nature of formal systems.
The MU-puzzle is a toy, but it is also a serious exercise in the study of formal systems. It is
a good way to start the study of this book, and the MU-puzzle is a recurring theme in the book.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the idea of strings and
rules. It is a contrived version of Gödel's famous UTM problem. The MU-puzzle consists of
strings of M's and U's, and three rules of transformation. The puzzle asks whether MU can be
obtained from MI. The MU-puzzle is a variant of the tq-system, which I discuss in detail in Part
I. The puzzle is simple, but it is very instructive because it is small and concrete, yet at the same
time it is rich enough to illustrate the essence of formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is a musical piece that is presented by two
players. In this dialogue, the Tortoise and Achilles are joined by a third person, the Crab, to
present two-part Invention. The dialogue itself is a dialogue of three voices, which I call the
Tortoise, Achilles, and Crab. The dialogue explores the idea of recursion in a very natural way. It
also introduces some of the concepts of recursion that are central to the book.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the question:
"Is Mathematics Formal?" They are joined by the Crab,
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a formal system, to illustrate the concept of
mechanical reasoning. The MU-puzzle consists of the three rules: 1. You can prefix 'U' to any
string. 2. You can substitute ' MU' for any 'I'. 3. You can drop 'III' from any string. The
problem is: Starting from the string "MI", can you get to "MU" using only the three rules? It's a
famous example of a formal system that is "complete" but not "sound"—in the sense that every
string that can be generated is a "theorem"—but none of them are "true" statements in any
formal system. It's meant to convey the idea that a formal system can be designed to generate all
true statements of a particular theory, but can also generate many "nonsense" statements. The
MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal system that is "complete" but not "sound"—in the sense
that every string that can be generated is a "theorem"—but none of them are "true" statements in
any formal system. The MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal system that is "complete" but not
---

Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader started. The MU-puzzle
consists of a single axiom and one single rule of inference. The axiom is MU. The only rule is that
if a string ends with U and has something before it, you can add a G before it. The MU-puzzle is to
see whether MUI can be derived from MU. The MU-puzzle is a variation of the MIU puzzle from
Gödel, Escher, Bach. The MU-puzzle is much simpler, and allows the reader to get started in
 exploring the notion of formal systems.
Three-Part Invention. The three-part invention is a set of three related pieces that together make up
a coherent whole. The three-part invention is designed to engage the reader in the process of
discovering the principles of formal systems.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A fugue by Bach, presented as a series of interconnected
mappings between different levels, akin to the MU-puzzle. The story of the MU-puzzle is that of
Achilles and the Tortoise, and the story of this Fugue is that of Achilles and the Tortoise, or of
Achilles and the Tortoise, but with some
---

Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe where only the letters M and U are allowed. The
 puzzle consists of four rules that can be applied to any string of M's and U's to transform it. The
 puzzle is to see whether you can get from the string MU to MUMU in the fewest number of steps.
 The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a formal system: an axiomatic system in which one can
 derive theorems from axioms in a purely syntactic fashion, without any reference to meaning.
 The MU-puzzle is perhaps the simplest possible formal system. It is a good example because it
 contains the essence of self-reference and therefore leads to an analogy with systems like the
 Propositional Calculus and Typographical Number Theory.
 Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. In this chapter, the Tortoise and Achilles are
 discussing the nature of mathematical meaning. They examine the question: What is the difference
 between the meaning of a word and the reference of a word? Then they explore how the meaning
 of a word is given by the role it plays in our language, and how the meaning of a mathematical
 statement is given by its relation to other statements. The Tortoise and Achilles are led to a
 discussion of the MU-p
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe consisting of the letters M and U. The MU-puzzle is a
set of rules for manipulating strings of letters. It is a simple formal system, but it is powerful enough
to be a Turing machine. The MU-puzzle has been used to illustrate the idea of recursion and
self-reference. The puzzle asks whether a certain string, MU, can be derived within the system. It
turns out that MU cannot be derived, but the reasoning required to show this is intricate. The MU
puzzle is a good example of a problem that is undecidable within the system. The MU-puzzle is
used in later chapters as an analogy for the human mind: a system that is powerful enough to
generate interesting questions, but which may never be able to answer them.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the question: Is
meaning in mathematics as literal as in other fields? In this chapter, they discuss the idea that in
mathematics, meaning is entirely relative, and that the form of the string is what is important, not
the meaning. The MU-puzzle is revisited in this context, and the idea of formal systems is
presented. The Tortoise and Achilles explore
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader started. It concerns the
system MU, which consists of the two symbols M and U. The puzzle is to see how to get from M
to MU. The MU-puzzle is a variant of the MIU puzzle of Lewis Carroll. I have added a third
axiom, so that the system is more powerful and the puzzle more challenging. The MU-puzzle is
very similar to problems of theorem-proving.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This chapter tries to get the reader to think about
the nature of meaning in mathematics. It also introduces the idea of reducing the meaning of a
theorem to its formal structure. The MU-puzzle is revisited in this context. The MU-puzzle is a
variant of the MIU puzzle of Lewis Carroll. I have added a third axiom, so that the system is more
powerful and the puzzle more challenging. The MU-puzzle is very similar to problems of theorem-proving.

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a formal system, which asks the question: What
does the MU-puzzle achieve? It is a minimal example of a system with an undecidable
proposition, which can be presented in terms of the MU-puzzle.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to get the reader to think about
strings, recursion, and formal systems. It is based on a system called MU, in which one can
derive new strings from the initial string MU following four rules. The puzzle is to see how to get
to a particular target string, say MIW. The MU-puzzle is a very simple version of the MU puzzle.
The puzzle is to find out whether the target string can be obtained from the starting string by
applying the given rules. The puzzle is to be solved by the reader, and is a good example of a
formal system, which is a set of rules for generating strings.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a concrete example of a
formal system. Meaning and Form in Mathematics is a discussion of how the meaning of
mathematical statements is independent of the particular symbols used. It also discusses the
notion of "form" in mathematics and how it relates to the form of the string in the MU-puzzle.
The discussion is related to the MU-puzzle. The concept of "formal systems" is introduced as a
set of rules for generating strings, and how meaning can be attached to these strings.
Chapter
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU, which consists of
strings of the letters M and U. The MU-puzzle is: Starting from the string M, can you derive the
string U? The puzzle is used to explain the concept of strings, rules, concatenation, and the
meaning of a formal system. It is shown how the MU-puzzle relates to the MU-puzzle presented
in the text.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is presented as an analogy to the concept of
two-part variation. The dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise is a dialogue that occurs in
two parts. The first part is presented, and then the second part is presented. The idea of recursion
is used to highlight the interplay between the two parts.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This chapter discusses the nature of mathematical
truth, especially from the perspective of mathematical Platonism. The concept of formal systems is
presented as a way to model the process of mathematical reasoning. The concept of meaning and
form in mathematics is used to explain why some formal systems are better than others for
describing certain kinds of mathematical truths.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Achilles, a hero of the Trojan war

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU-System. The
Problem: Prove that "MU" is a theorem of the MU-System. The MU-puzzle is a good example of
how abstract reasoning can go wrong when we try to leap too quickly to conclusions.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is presented as the basis for the first two dialogues
of the book. The Tortoise and Achilles are "invented" by Zeno. The first dialogue is "The
Tortoise and Achilles", and the second is "Achilles and the Tortoise". Very short, it simply gives the
flavor of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. Formal systems, the role of meaning in math-
ematics, and the formalist view. The MU-puzzle is revisited, and how formal systems work.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria written for Achilles, which is a response to "The
Tortoise and Achilles". It is a reflection on the nature of consciousness and the mind.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The idea of figure and ground in mathematics and music is
presented. The third of the dialogues is "Contracrostip
---
